<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 415, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 769, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 742, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the stability of a wooden block resting on a bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
A strip is attached by a nail to the centre of the top of the block and is able to rotate, as shown in Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 149, 922, 350]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 367, 265, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[682, 367, 752, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 397, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
A load of mass \(m\) is attached to the free end of the strip at point P. The student is investigating the position of the strip indicated by angle \(\theta\), as shown in Fig. 1.2, at which the block just topples.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 444, 576, 463]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(m\) and \(\theta\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 475, 598, 494]]<|/det|>
\[\alpha Vw = 2mL\cos \theta -mw\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 507, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
where \(\alpha\) is a constant, \(V\) is the volume of the block, \(w\) is the width of the block and \(L\) is the distance between the centre of the nail and the centre of the load.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 553, 718, 571]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(m\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 567, 667, 586]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 599, 816, 617]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 613, 562, 632]]<|/det|>
In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 648, 395, 665]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 673, 411, 691]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 698, 349, 715]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 723, 351, 740]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 747, 450, 765]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the oscillations of a mass attached to an arrangement of springs. Fig. 2.1 shows a mass attached to two springs connected in series.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[338, 114, 640, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 532, 410]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
The student determines the spring constant \(k\) for the arrangement of the springs. A stopwatch is used to measure the time \(t\) for 20 oscillations. The measurement of \(t\) is repeated and the average period \(T\) is determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 841, 503]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different arrangements and different numbers of springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 569, 533]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(T\) and \(k\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 543, 551, 577]]<|/det|>
\[T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{M}{k}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 592, 297, 609]]<|/det|>
where \(M\) is the mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 146, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 662, 642]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(T^2\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{k}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 653, 500, 672]]<|/det|>
Determine an expression for the gradient.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 98]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 675, 102]]<|/det|> Values of \(k\), \(\frac{1}{k}\) and the measurements of \(t\) are given in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 104, 917, 416]]<|/det|>
\(k/\mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)\(\frac{1}{k}/\mathrm{mN}^{-1}\)\(t/\mathrm{s}\)\(t/\mathrm{s}\)\(T/\mathrm{s}\)\(T^{2}/\mathrm{s}^{2}\)
7.90.1322.222.6
110.09119.218.8
150.06716.616.0
240.04212.813.4
320.03111.011.8
490.0209.89.0
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 432, 534, 452]]<|/det|> # Fig. 2.2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 626, 483]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(T / \mathrm{s}\) and \(T^{2} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) in Fig. 2.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 479, 541, 498]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(T\) and \(T^{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 481, 920, 500]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 144, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 510, 180, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 520, 532]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(T^{2} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) against \(\frac{1}{k} /\mathrm{mN}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 532, 401, 551]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(T^{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 533, 920, 552]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 564, 178, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 920, 597]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 580, 920, 598]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 611, 181, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 609, 920, 643]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 858, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a) and (c)(iii), determine the value of \(M.\) Include an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 256, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
<form>M = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 180, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 554, 305]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(M.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................. % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 144, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 489, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
Determine the spring constant \(k\) for an arrangement of springs using the same mass that would have a period of \(2.50 \pm 0.01 \text{s}\). Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 755, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
<form>k = .................................................... N m⁻¹ [2]
